title: Friday, 16th October, 2015

Chinese investors are in pole position to shape the future of Formula One (F1) motor racing as one of the country’s largest investment firms backs an $8.5bn (£5.5bn) takeover bid for the sport.

Sky News can reveal that China Media Capital (CMC) is leading a group of Chinese firms who want to invest roughly $1.5bn (£970m) in an offer being assembled by Stephen Ross, owner of the Miami Dolphins American football team.

Mr Ross’s consortium is understood to be planning to write in the coming days to CVC Capital Partners, F1’s controlling shareholder, to seek a 90-day period of exclusivity during which it would hold detailed talks with Bernie Ecclestone, F1’s chief executive, and undertake due diligence.

The firm prefers to invest in the cultural, technology, media, entertainment, consumer, medical treatment, and telecommunication sectors. It prefers to invest in and outside China. China Media Capital was founded in 2009 and is based in Shanghai, China with an additional office in Beijing, China.

Following convictions on 20 November 2012 of two counts of fraud by abuse of position, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has banned Kweku Mawuli Adoboli from performing any function in relation to any regulated financial activity. Mr Adoboli abused his position as a senior trader at UBS AG causing UBS AG losses amounting to $2.25bn.

Mr Adoboli’s conviction and resulting sentencing to seven years’ imprisonment, following an investigation by the City of London Police and prosecution by the Crown Prosecution Service, demonstrate a clear and serious lack of honesty and integrity. In reaching its decision, the FCA has considered all the relevant circumstances and the severity of the risk posed by Mr Adoboli to consumers and financial institutions, and to confidence in the market generally.

BE

Speaking of drugs, best get AstraZeneca out of the way.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,120, down 1 (-0.02%), High: 4,133, Low: 4,042, Volume: 1.12m
BE

SaxaDapa ain't great.

11:17 am
BE

FDA wanting more data on the diabetes pill.

BE

Analysts are talking about a delay of up to a year, rather than taking a possible blockbuster out of the pipeline.

BE

Basically, will need resubmitted by early 2016.

11:18 am
PM

ok

BE

With new trials required.

BE

more clinical data are required to support the application, (including)
clinical trial data from ongoing or completed studies and may require
information from new studies

11:19 am
BE

.... says AZN.

BE

Here's MOST.

BE

A company contact suggests FDA does not
have specific safety concern about the risk of ketoacidosis with Farxiga or
hospitalization for heart failure, two recently added or about to be added
warnings on the US label of the respective drugs. However, we understand that
clarifications could come from existing trials but that new trials may also be
required.

11:19 am
BE

Which its house broker, so you imagine its company contacts are quite reliable.

BE

least 8-10m delay, up to a few years with 3% EPS downside. Depending
on what is required by the FDA, we estimate a c 8-10m delay in a best case
scenario where AZN could resubmit the drug in early 2016 with a 6m class 2
resubmission, and up to a few years delay should it have to run new clinical
trials. Consensus anticipates c$1.0bn peak sales for SaxaDapa (c 3% of group)
vs MSe $1.8bn. Of note, SaxaDapa is also currently being reviewed by the EU
EMA with a possible action date in 1H 16.

BE

And Barclays.

11:20 am
BE

$800m 2020 consensus forecasts: is further data required to support the application? In an unexpected development this morning, AZN announced the receipt of a CRL from the FDA related to the filing of the oral diabetes combination product containing currently marketed products Onglyza (saxagliptin, DPP-IV) and Forxiga (dapagliflozin, SGLT-2). Details are limited at this juncture with the degree of additional data requirement unknown, yet according to the company the CRL does not highlight any issues related to hospitalizations with Heart Failure (hHF) nor diabetic Keto acidosis (DKA). It is hoped that the data already submitted can resolve the issues identified with the filing yet there clearly exists the potential for delays associated with further studies and the submission of a new NDA. Consensus saxa/dapa FDC estimates for 2020 stand at $800m (3% of group) with its launch hoped to help accelerate the Forxiga franchise in a period where US Onglyza promotion and sales are in decline post the hHF signal. Current consensus estimates for the entire Onglyza/Farxiga/FDC franchise stand at $4bn in 2020E, which equates to a 25-30% global revenue share and assumes that the SGLT2 class can be successfully developed outside the US on the back of positive outcomes data. We assume the Onglyza/Farxiga/FDC franchise captures a more conservative 17% global revenue share and note that the Onglyza franchise has slipped to a 12% revenue share and the Farxiga franchise a 25% revenue share in the US. Given the strong incumbent positions of JNJ’s Invokana franchise and Merck’s Januvia franchise (with an SGLT2 combination launch end 2018E), together with the positive outcomes benefit recently demonstrated by Lilly’s Jardiance in the EMPA-REG trial, resolution of today’s setback is important for the future dynamics of AZN’s diabetes franchise.

BE

What happens next and how long do we need to wait for Farxiga outcomes data? As stated, the saxa/dapa FDC is seen as a key component of Astra’s mid-term oral diabetes franchise strategy and is hoped to boost revenue growth in the face of likely increased market share gains from Merck and Lilly. If the data already submitted can resolve the issues flagged by the FDA, a 3 month consultation/data cutting period followed by 6 month FDA review could lend to a potential mid-2016 approval, yet further data requirements could push this date back to 2018 on our estimates. AZN is currently conducting a cardiovascular outcomes study (DECLARE) hoped to mirror the positive findings of Lilly’s EMPA-REG study (discussed here) and while the official read-out date is scheduled for 2019, given the incidence rate and recruitment status our analysis points to the potential for a late 2016/early 2017 completion. Provided the data generated is sufficient we could expect H1 2017 filing and potential approval in early 2018.

BE

What about the competitive landscape? Timing of a potential approval is clearly key for Astra to differentiate its diabetes franchise especially given the ongoing saxa/dapa combination studies of Merck and Pfizer. According to clinicaltrials.gov, 8 studies are currently underway and fully recruited investigating Merck’s class leading DPP-IV Januvia (sitagliptin) and Pfizer’s SGLT-2 ertugliflozin. Expected completion timelines point to likely H2 2017 filing and potential approval towards the end of 2018 thus the sooner AZN can satisfy the FDA and get its FDC approved the greater chance of franchise development and stability. As things currently stand Onglyza continues to lose market share to Januvia and Farxiga is expected to come under increased competition from Jardiance given supportive EMPA-REG CV outcome claims.

BE

11:23 am

BE

Ah. Man noodles. Those cornflour things with a little stock packet that work as a kind of Bachelor Chow.

BE

29p a packet, generally.

BE

Anyway, Nestle's China and India sales have been underperforming forecasts for a while.

11:27 am
BE

"Nutrition" -- I'm not quite sure what that means, but it's probably not those noodles -- also gone negative.

BE

There's also a problem with drug rebates for US skincare.

BE

Suffice to say, a lot of this is Nestle specific. But the general theme of consumer-led EM growth isn't looking too pretty either.

11:29 am
BE

Here's Canaccord.

BE

Nestle 9M organic sales, at +4.2%, are well below the +4.7% consensus and imply
weaker growth of around 3.6% in the discrete Q3. This has obliged Nestle to capitulate
on its FY2015 guidance, which has been reduced from "around 5%" to "around 4.5%",
with no change to the expected "improvement" in margins. Pricing across the board is
softer than consensus estimates (+2.2% for the 9M v +2.7% expected). While some
softening in the recovery in China had been flagged at the H1 stage, as had the likely
continuation of the Maggi recall in India, the impact of both of these has been greater
than anticipated by the market. The Maggi recall has depressed 9M sales by c30bps
and relisting of the product will be delayed somewhat compared with the original hopes.
Across infant nutrition, pricing has been hit by weakening Dairy prices. Elsewhere, the
decision to change the drug rebate policy in the US in Nestle Skin Health has had a
further negative impact. These factors have more than offset the continued robust
growth in N America and Europe.

BE

Given Nestle's relatively strong share price over the last quarter, and the contrast in its
Q3 growth of c3.6% with Unilever's +5.7%, we think the shares will suffer a meaningful
correction today. We keep our target of CHF70/share.
On the positive side, results in N America continue to be encouraging - particularly
reflecting seven straight months of recovery in US Frozen Foods following the product
relaunches; in Latin America Brazil has been surprisingly resilient, while Mexico has
accelerated (with the coffee business being strong in both of those markets); W
Europe was in line with our own and market expectations albeit within the continuing
deflationary environment. Both Russia and Ukraine grew strongly, helped by pricing.

Pursuant to Rule 2.6(c) of the City Code on Takeovers and Mergers (the "Code"), the Company has requested a 28 day extension to the period of time whereby Nuna Minerals A/S ("Nuna") must, under Rule 2.6 (a) of the Code, either announce a firm intention to make an offer for the Company, or announce that it does not intend to make an offer. London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) today announces the launch of CurveGlobal, a new interest rate derivatives venture with a number of major dealer banks: Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays, Citi, Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan and Société Générale, together with the Chicago Board Options Exchange (collectively, "the Investors"). The Investors and LSEG have signed definitive terms in respect of the venture and additional shareholders are expected to join in the coming months.

PM

CurveGlobal plans to initially offer trading in Short Term Interest Rate (STIR) futures in Euribor and Short Sterling and Long Term Interest Rate (LTIR) futures in Bund, Bobl, Schatz and Gilts. Additional products are expected to be rolled out following the launch phase. All products designed and supported by CurveGlobal are intended to be admitted to trading on LSEG's wholly owned subsidiary, London Stock Exchange plc's (LSE plc), London Stock Exchange Derivatives Market, and cleared through LCH.Clearnet, subject to regulatory approvals and necessary licences.

Zambia shuts bars, cancels football matches to pray and fast
Economic crisis triggered by copper slump, power shortages

11:47 am
PM

That’s what Zambian President Edgar Lungu wants his people to pray for on a national day of devotion and fasting on Sunday to reverse a decline in the world’s worst currency and fix a litany of problems from plunging copper prices to electricity shortages.
All bars, nightclubs and entertainment venues have been instructed by the government to shut on the day, while the Football Association of Zambia has canceled domestic games. Church leaders are rallying their members to heed the president’s call in a nation where more than 80 percent of the 15 million population are Christian.

BE

Should probably note Tui

Tui AG (TUI:LSE): Last: 1,214, down 17 (-1.38%), High: 1,240, Low: 1,212, Volume: 257.37k
BE

Which seems to have had a bit of a communication breakdown

11:50 am
BE

So. Tui post the Tui Travel buyout was promising a 10% dividend bump.

BE

Which it still is. But it's not a permanent 10% dividend bump.

BE

It's only for this year and next.

11:51 am
BE

Which wasn't entirely clear previously.

BE

At least, it wasn't entirely clear to Morgan Stanley, which sends round this rather terse memo on the subject this morning.

BE

We cut 2017e DPS 12% following clarification that the 10% extra
increase TUI had announced for 2015 & 2016 is really a one-off
"bonus". Our DPS estimates were in-line with consensus, and the
yield remains 4%. While disappointing, we see this as a
communication issue rather than anything fundamental.

11:51 am
BE

It's a quite unfortunate "communication issue"

BE

TUI has clarified its dividend guidance following its collation of
consensus forecasts post financial year end. The dividend guidance in the
October 2014 merger document was as follows:
Following Completion, the Combined Group intends to adopt a dividend policy
in line with TUI Travel's present progressive dividend policy under which
dividends grow broadly in line with earnings. Provided the performance of the
Combined Group develops in line with expectations, the Combined Group will
target an increase in its dividend per share for the financial years 2014/15 and
2015/16 of 10% in excess of the underlying growth in the Combined Group’s
earnings per share. This is subject to adequate balance sheet capacity,
recommendations by the Executive Board of TUI AG and the Supervisory Board
of TUI AG and approval at the respective TUI AG Annual General Meeting in
the relevant year.

BE

This was further discussed at the Capital Markets Day in May this year,
where TUI explained that the 2014/15 base would include the TUI Travel
interim dividend to give a €0.445 base, and that the underlying growth rates in
2015 and 2016 would be in relation to underlying EBITA (2015 guidance now
12.5-15.0%, 2016 target at least 10%). The chart below was in this
presentation.

11:52 am
BE

PM

That is a bit terse

BE

Yup, definite "issue" with the communication.

11:53 am
BE

We took the additional 10% growth in these years to be recurring, in
other words to build a higher base off which future dividends would
grow. This led to our previous DPS estimates of €0.56 in 2015 (+25%, i.e.
€0.445 base plus 15% EBITA growth plus 10% boost), €0.65 in 2016 (+16%, i.e.
€0.56 base plus 10% boost on €0.445 base plus 10% EBITA growth), and €0.74
in 2017 (+15%, i.e. €0.65 base plus 15% EPS growth). The company has now
clarified that the 10% increases in 2015 and 2016 are a one-off "bonus", so in
other words they reverse, leading to the drops in our dividend estimates, and
leading to lower DPS growth than we had expected in 2017. We continue to
assume 2015e at €0.56, and now estimate 2016 at €0.62 (+11%, i.e. €0.445
2014 base, plus 10% bonus, plus 2015e's 16% EBITA growth, plus 2016e's
12% EBITA growth), and 2017e at €0.65 (+5%, i.e. €0.445 2014 base, plus
2015e's 16% EBITA growth, plus 2016e's 12% EBITA growth, plus 2017e's 13%
EBITA growth). This is perhaps more easily seen in the table below. This is a
12% cut to our 2017 dividend estimate, and would be more were it not for us
now linking DPS growth to our actual EBITA estimates rather than the EBITA
growth targets (we are above its targets).

BE

Bit of a misstep, certainly.

undefined
11:54 am
BE

Speaking of Morgan Stanley, as we were ..........

BE

They're downgrading Burberry this morning

BE

Post its absolutely terrible numbers yesterday.

11:55 am
BE

And the Hugo Boss profit warning overnight, of course, which adds to my theory that sub-luxury luxury isn't cutting it any more.

BE

There's a place in the world for Louis Vuitton and Boggi and the like because the super-rich remain as offensive as ever.

BE

..... . But who cares if your shirt's made by Burberry or Hugo Boss? The doorman at Novikov won't.

11:57 am
BE

Here's MOST.

BE

Burberry's profit performance suggests revenues are becoming more
expensive to deliver. As we recently discussed, we think Burberry's longterm
prospects remain among the best in the industry, but were concerned
that the cost of new sales could be becoming more expensive. The
disappointing sales performance in Q2 (-4% LFL end Sept) and only £20m of
discretionary cost reduction for this year (just 2% of FY15 retail/wholesale
opex base, ex rentals) now suggest to us limited cost structure flexibility.

BE

Potential volatility in LFL with lack of cost transparency raises forecast
risk. We expected a slowdown in LFL momentum in Q2, but were surprised by
the magnitude of the decline (-4% vs MSe +4%). Whilst Europe has been
impacted by a slowdown in tourist related demand (particularly the Chinese), if
the Americas region does not return to positive territory in H216 we would
struggle to maintain confidence in Burberry's assumption of a return to 'midsingle
digit' growth in LFL in H2 (necessary to meet expected FY16 adj PBT of
£445m). We forecast +2% LFL in H2 and FY16 adj PBT of £421m. For every 1%
change in LFL, we estimate this impacts EBIT by ~3%.

11:57 am
BE

EPS cuts of 4% FY16 and 9-10% pa post FY17; PT now 1400p. We reflect
management's planned savings of £40-50m in FY16 (£20m discretional cost
and £20-30m performance pay related). However in FY17 we assume ongoing
cost saving of £30m pa – this results in a -9% reduction to EPS. Our DCF
derived PT is lowered from 1650p to 1400p reflecting (i) 10% reduction to our
LT earnings and (ii) our revised long term growth assumption of 2.5% (was
3.0%) given we now see more uncertainty around the company's profit profile.
Our new PT implies a target P/E of 19.4x cal '16 (was 21.1x).
Move to EW - cost clarity needed to provide confidence. On our revised
forecasts Burberry trades on 18.0x cal P/E in 2016e (vs 19x peers). We think
transparency around the cost base is key to a re-rating.
